page.title: 05THE FARMS AROUND HOWNAM
page.content: The area around the village of Hownam in the Scottish Borders, takes in two complete farms, and some of the ground of eight others.They are all upland stock rearing establishments,sheep being the most predominant. The number of animals vary throughout the months, but during the summer the ground is most heavily stocked, before the years young animals are sold. The land will carry 2202 stock sheep,with a further 2209 lambs from spring time to autumn. Also there are 227 stock cattle with 224 young animals,some this years calves,and some last years, most of which will be sold before the winter. The majority of stock spend the cold weather outside,both sheep and cattle getting hay to supplement the receding grass,and turnips,either eaten in the fields or laid down to them. There are no pigs kept,and little grain grown.
